Laboratory of Plasma-Catalysis (R3.5) Center of Research and Services - Diponegoro University (CORES-DU) Universitas Diponegoro Semarang Central Java 50275 Indonesia In this study, the reactivation and modification of the spent Residue Fluid Catalytic Cracking (RFCC) catalyst using sulfuric acid and citric acid as acids treatment was evaluated by varying the acid solution concentrations. The effect of acid types and acid-solution concentrations on structural, textural, and acidic properties of spent RFCC catalyst was observed using X-ray diffraction, X-ray fluorescence, N2-sorption and pyridine-probed Fourier transform infrared measurements. Catalytic cracking of palm oil was used to evaluate the catalytic activity of the acid-treated catalysts. All the results showed the different beneficial effects of the sulfuric acid- and citric acid- treatments on the physicochemical properties of the modified catalyst with an improvement of surface area and pore volume of catalysts as well as the crystallinity due to the metal and matrix material removal. The sulfuric acid-treated catalysts have higher Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) ratio than the citric acid treatment, while the citric acid-treated catalysts have lower B/L ratio due to the enhancement of Lewis acid site. The acid-treated catalysts showed better performance than the non-treated catalyst. The selectivity of the kerosene-diesel range product fraction increased with the acid concentrations treatment. Graphical abstract Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Acid treatment Catalyst properties Spent RFCC catalyst Catalytic cracking Kerosene-diesel 1 Introduction In the refinery process, residue fluid catalytic cracking (RFCC) catalyst converts heavy oil or residue into more valuable products. As a waste catalyst of RFCC unit, a spent RFCC catalyst has been deactivated during the refinery process due to the heavy metal contaminant in the low-quality oil feedstocks and carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, which can reduce the catalysts’ active sites. The most common metal contaminants on the spent RFCC catalyst are Ni, V, and Fe [1]. Metal contaminants can influence the catalytic activity, including increasing the tendency of the coke formation and hydrogen gas production due to the dehydrogenation reaction and reducing the yield of gasoline and product conversion, as reported by Sadeghbeigi [2]. In addition, rare earth metals, such as: La, Ce, and Pr, are widely designed in catalysis due to the necessity for increasing the hydrothermal stability and more active catalyst with better performance [3,4]. However, the landfill of the spent RFCC catalyst became costly and complex because of the high amount of metal contaminants and rare earths on the spent RFCC catalyst requiring the pre-treatment step. Therefore, recovery and reusing waste spent RFCC catalyst is highly recommended [5,6]. Several methods have been reported to regenerate and reactivate the spent RFCC catalyst. One of the most applied methods is an acid treatment. The use of chemical solutions has some advantages, such as low-cost requirements and possible recovery of leachates [7]. In several studies, spent RFCC reactivation resulted in the preferred modification of the catalyst and a better catalytic product. For example, spent RFCC catalyst, regenerated using washing oxalic acid and citric acid, has a higher conversion and gasoline yield compared to equilibrium catalyst (E-cat) [6]. It was due to the increased acid site of the regenerated catalyst, so that the catalytic activity increased. In addition, meso- and macro- pore volumes were increased and the fine particles were removed during regeneration [6]. The acid treatment was also applied to the FCC E-cat for biomass pyrolysis [8]. It was reported that the FCC E-cat treated with HNO3 has a higher specific surface area, pore-volume, and weak/strong acid sites than the untreated catalyst so that the liquid product of biomass pyrolysis could be increased [8]. The spent FCC reactivated using mixed acids (acetic acid and oxalic acid) resulted in expanding the pore volume due to the loss of heavy metal contaminants and dealumination of Al on the catalyst so that the catalysis process with heavy oil as raw materials produces higher gasoline and diesel yields than spent FCC [9]. The spent RFCC as a deactivated zeolite-based catalyst is assumed to have adjustable textural and acidic properties, environmental friendliness, and insignificantly active [10]. Zeolite catalysts can be reused in other processes requiring an acidic catalyst for catalytic activity after some treatments, where the treatment is needed to reactivate or modify this catalyst to be appropriate to other catalysis processes. Production of renewable fuels and waste disposal are two of the significant interests facing the world today because both energy derived from petroleum fuels and environmental concerns will define the future economic potential [11]. Catalytic cracking of palm oil to produce biofuels is one of the promising processes in producing alternative energy, where biofuels have been widely used as a mixture or direct replacement of fossil fuels [12]. Palm oil is the most favorable raw material for biofuel production because of the high content of long-chain hydrocarbons [13]. In addition, palm oil is one of the most widely consumed vegetable oils worldwide and continues to improve its production. Especially Indonesia is the world's largest palm oil producer reached almost 62% of total world production. The catalytic cracking is preferably used to convert gasoline, kerosene, and diesel fractions due to comparatively lower reaction temperature and lower-cost operations [14]. Zeolites perform a critical function in the cracking of vegetable oil [12]. Since the spent RFCC catalyst is zeolite-based, reactivation and modified spent RFCC with acid treatment are expected to produce the desired catalytic properties in the cracking reactions. As mentioned before, the acid treatment has been reported as a good process to regenerate the spent RFCC catalyst to generate the mesopore structure. However, the discussion about the effect of acid treatment on spent RFCC catalyst acid sites was not reported in the previous study. The main goal of this study is to produce an interesting impact on reactivation and modification of the waste spent RFCC catalyst using sulfuric acid- and citric acid- treatments. Sulfuric acid is a strong inorganic acid which is proven to remove the deposited metal and increase the Brønsted acid site [13,15]. In addition, citric acid is a weak organic acid and a good chelating agent [15]. The effect of various concentrations of sulfuric acid- and citric acid- treatments solutions on catalyst properties, structural, textural, and acidic, have not been studied. Previously, we have regenerated the Brønsted/Lewis acid sites on the SRFCC catalyst by some acid treatments, which in turn, the catalyst can be reused as a suitable catalyst for palm oil cracking [13] and hydrocracking [16] to liquid fuels. However, the detailed testing of various concentrations of sulfuric acid- and citric acid- treatments solutions on the correlation between catalyst characteristics and palm oil's catalytic cracking to biofuels needs to be explored here. On the other hand, to the best of our knowledge, the study on the effect of sulfuric and citric acid treatments to modify the spent RFCC catalyst for catalytic cracking of palm oil is very limited. 2 Materials and method 2.1 Materials and catalysts preparation The zeolite catalyst used in this study denoted as the spent RFCC catalyst, was supplied from the Indonesia petroleum refinery as a waste. Sulfuric acid (96.1%, Mallinckrodt) and citric acid (99%, Merck) were used for the catalyst preparation. First, the spent RFCC catalyst was dried in an oven (Memmert) at 110 °C for 8 h and calcined in a muffle furnace (Thermolyne Benchtop) at 550 °C for 4 h. The calcined sample was then added to citric acid or sulfuric acid solution at 80 °C under stirring for 3 h with a solid to liquid ratio of 1:10 w/v [17] and varied acid solution concentrations (0.3; 0.5; 0.7; 1.0; and 1.5 M). Afterward, the catalyst was filtered, washed several times using demineralized water until it was neutral to remove the excess acid. The washed catalyst was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 8 h and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. Finally, the prepared catalyst was pelleted and crushed into particle sizes of 14–16 mesh. The obtained acid-treated samples were remarked as S(X)-RFCC for sulfuric acid-treated catalyst, and C(X)-RFCC for citric acid-treated catalyst, where X stands for the acid solution concentration. For comparison, the non-treated spent RFCC catalyst was prepared using calcination in a furnace at 550 °C for 4 h and remarked as RFCC. 2.2 Characterizations of catalysts Several methods were implemented to characterize the physicochemical properties and structural characteristics of non-treated and acid-treated catalysts. The metal composition and the Si/Al ratio of non-treated and acid-treated samples were determined using the X-ray Fluorescence (XRF) analysis method (Rigaku Supermini 200 Benchtop WDXRF Spectrometer). The crystal structure of the samples was determined by the X-ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis (Shimadzu 7000). The catalyst was irradiated using Cu-Kα radiation at 30 kV and 30 mA, where diffraction patterns were obtained from 2θ = 10 to 90° with a scanning speed of 3°/min. The percentage of crystallinity was obtained by dividing the total area of the crystal peaks and the total all peaks (both crystalline and amorphous) area (Eq. (1)). The textural characterization of samples was carried out by N2-physisorption analysis and performed in an apparatus Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 at 77 K. The surface area (S BET) was determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Meanwhile, the pore size distribution and pore volume were obtained using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) and t-plot methods. Finally, to determine the acid sites concentration and acid site types of non-treated and acid-treated catalyst, the samples were characterized by pyridine (probe molecule) adsorption, which was performed using an FTIR analyzer (Shimadzu). (1) C r y s t a l l i n i t y ( % ) = C r y s t a l p e a k s a r e a T o t a l p e a k s a r e a × 100 2.3 Catalysts performance test for palm oil Refined palm oil purchased from the local brand was used as a feedstock for the catalytic cracking. The catalysts performance was evaluated in a continuous fixed-bed reactor with a diameter of 1 in (Fig. 1 ). A fixed-bed catalytic reactor was chosen instead of a fluidized-bed reactor, because it is easier to be installed and handled. The reactor is a stainless-steel tube placed in an electric furnace to heat up the reactor to maintain at temperature of 450 °C. The main composition of refined palm oil determined using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis (QP2010S SHIMADZU, DB-1 column) was Palmitic acid (C16:0) 43.30%, and Oleic acid (C18:1) 18.51%, the rest component was listed in Table 1 . Before the reaction, the 5 g-catalyst was loaded into the fixed-bed reactor over supported glass wool, and then the reactor system was flushed with N2 gas (99.9%, UHP) at an approximate flow rate of 100 mL/min for 15 min to remove the presence of oxygen completely. The feedstock was pumped into the reactor at the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.365 min−1 by using a peristaltic pump (RZ1030-BX) after the required reactor temperature was accomplished and stable. Afterward, the product of the reactor was condensed into a liquid product stated as an Organic Liquid Product (OLP). The other byproducts of the catalytic cracking process were non-condensable gases and coke deposition. The liquid products were collected at 3 h of reaction after steady-state conditions were reached. In this study, the steady-state conditions were assumed to occur after the initial reaction time of 30 min. The composition of OLP as crude cracking product was determined according to the boiling point in a batch-distillation apparatus at atmospheric pressure to calculate the amount of gasoline and kerosene-diesel fraction. The temperature range of 39–204 °C (CAS 86290-81-5) was intended for gasoline fraction, while the kerosene-diesel was collected at a temperature range of 204–370 °C (3675 K/24/DJM/2006; 17.K/72/DJM/1999). The kerosene-diesel fraction product was then analyzed by GC-MS (QP2010S SHIMADZU, DB-1 column) to identify the chemical compositions of this product. The yield and selectivity values were obtained on a mass basis of the cracking product. Thus, the yield of product (OLP, non-condensable gas, and coke deposition) is given by Eq. (2), relating the mass of cracking product (m product) with the total mass of palm oil feedstock (m feed). The selectivity of the distilled fraction was calculated by Eq. (3), relating the desired amount of gasoline or kerosene-diesel fraction (m distilled frac.) with the mass of liquid product of catalytic cracking palm oil (m OLP). Table 2 shows the XRF results of the modified catalysts and unmodified spent RFCC. It can be seen that the main metals are Si and Al with numerous heavy metals of relatively low content. As the main metals are Si and Al, it can be deduced that the spent RFCC catalyst was the silica-alumina- or zeolite-based catalyst. Typically, sodium (Na) cation can be found in the zeolite-based material. However, as can be seen in Table 2, Na metal is not found, even in the non-treated spent RFCC (catalyst raw material). It should be noted that the spent RFCC catalyst (catalyst raw material) in this study is the spent catalyst from the petroleum refinery plant waste. Therefore, the unfound Na metal in the catalysts might be caused by the exchanged process with heavy metals contaminants during the deactivation in the refinery process plant. In addition, the other heavy metals could appear because of the catalyst design or because of the poisoning process. However, as numerous heavy metals are found, it is reasonable to conclude that the presence of heavy metals on the spent RFCC is because of the catalyst deactivation through metals poisoning. It is possible because the catalysts for fluid catalytic cracking can be poisoned by heavy metals, such as nickel and vanadium [4], depending on the contaminant content of the processed oil. From the Table 2, the acid-treated catalysts have a significant influence on the removal of heavy metals. Both acids can remove the heavy metals in the spent RFCC catalyst. However, the average amount of metals elimination of sulfuric acid-treated catalyst was higher than the citric acid-treated catalyst (Table 2). This phenomenon explains that eliminating heavy metals of the catalysts using sulfuric acid treatment is better than that by citric acid. For example, S(0.3)-RFCC and S(0.5)-RFCC samples eliminated Ni as much as 62% and 32% when using the sulfuric acid treatment, while the citric acid treatment did not eliminate any Ni at the same concentration. It is believed that this difference is due to the different acid strength of both acids. Citric acid is a weak organic acid, while sulfuric acid is a strong inorganic acid. Strong acid can easily dissolve the metal contaminant on the catalyst. Therefore, sulfuric acid has higher metal removal than citric acid. Astuti et al. [15] also reported that sulfuric acid has a higher metal dissolution rate than citric acid. The acid solutions can directly remove metal ions by hydrogen ions or specifically adsorbing mineral surfaces making soluble complexes with metal [15]. As can be observed in Table 2, sulfuric acid can remove all of V metal on the spent RFCC catalyst. However, citric acid results in a low V removal. As can be seen, there is no trend about the V dissolution using citric acid even though the V content on the spent RFCC catalyst is low enough. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that citric acid is not able to release V metal on the spent RFCC catalyst properly because citric acid is a weak organic acid. According to Cho et al. [6], washing medium (oxalic acid, citric acid, H2O2) influenced the removal of V metal which confirms the V metal elimination. On the other hand, Ni could not be eliminated like as V metal removal, and even some samples were not eliminated at all. From Table 2, the Si/Al ratio of the acid-treated catalyst are increased. It can be observed that the acids treatment led to a selective dealumination and desilication process on the zeolite. The Si/Al ratio increased with acids concentration for all the treated materials with sulfuric acid and citric acid treatments. It indicates that the acids concentration can increase the dealumination and desilication processes. Jin et al. [18] also reported that citric acid treatment tended to attack the P-Al-Si specific domain and caused selective desilication in the SAPO-34 zeolite framework. Likewise, the sulfuric acid treatment caused the dissolution of Al and Si, but the dealumination process remains dominant in the acid treatment [19]. 3.1.2 Crystal structure and phases identification analysis using XRD method The XRD patterns of non-treated and acid-treated spent RFCC catalyst are shown in Fig. 2 . As can be seen, all catalysts have main intense peaks at 2θ = 10.4°, 12.1°, 15.9°, 19.0°, 20.7°, 24.0°, and 27.5°. It indicates that the catalysts have faujasite phase structure. In addition, a diffuse peak or broad background over 2θ 10°–30° has been found in all catalysts. This broad background can be attributed to the presence of amorphous silica [20]. The crystallinity of XRD diffraction patterns between 10° and 90° was calculated using Eq. (1) and listed in Table 3 . It reveals that the crystallinity of S-RFCC and C-RFCC samples increased as the acid-treatment concentration increased. Thus, it suggests that the acids treatment is beneficial in increasing the crystallinity of spent RFCC catalyst. The fundamental reason could be attributed to the changing of crystal surface or amorphous material corroded with the acid treatment. As reported by Wang et al. [10], acid treatment could remove extra-framework Al (EFAl) species from the surface. In addition, Fan et al. [21] also reported that the acid treatment could increase the relative crystallinity of zeolite due to the removal of intraporous EFAl. Furthermore, the acids treatment of the spent RFCC catalyst removed blockage metals and left the crystal structure so that the crystallinity of acid-treated samples increased. In addition, the pointing of the XRD peaks could be observed in Fig. 2, which indicates the increased in crystallinity after the acid treatment. However, from Fig. 2, the crystallinity of acid-treated samples does not change obviously. As reported by Istadi et al. [13], the acid treatment does not significantly change the structure or crystal phase of the spent RFCC catalyst. 3.1.3 Surface area and pore properties of catalysts The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77 K of non- and acid-treated samples are shown in Fig. 3 . The adsorption isotherm of spent RFCC catalyst tends to dip upwards at low P/Po. However, at higher P/Po, the catalyst adsorption isotherm continues to rise slowly, however, when P/Po is close to 1 the catalyst adsorption isotherm rises rapidly, indicating that the sorption isotherm of spent RFCC catalyst belongs to type IV isotherms based on IUPAC. The characteristic of the type IV isotherm is its hysteresis loop, which is mainly associated with the presence of mesopores. In addition, the N2 sorption isotherm curve increased upwards y-axis, indicating the adsorption volume of the spent RFCC catalyst increased as acid-treatment concentration increased. The quantitative exposition of textural analysis results shows in Table 3. It clearly observed that all acid-treated catalysts have larger surface area (S BET), total pore volume (V total), micropore volume (V micro), and also mesopore volume (V meso) compared to the non-treated catalyst. However, the sulfuric acid-treated catalysts show higher values than citric acid-treated samples at the same acid concentration, except for S(0.5)-RFCC. The surface area and total pore volume of the acid-treated catalysts increased with the acid-treatment solution, which is primarily due to the removing blockage metal on pores by acid treatment. It is suggested that the heavy metals elimination process during acid treatment can open the closed pores to increase the pore volumes and surface areas [9]. According to the characterization results of XRF (Table 2), some metals on the catalysts are removed during the acid treatment, either sulfuric acid or citric acid. It can be suggested that the acid-treated catalysts have higher surface area and pore volume due to the metal removal. It is true since the number of metals released of sulfuric acid-treated catalysts was more significant than citric acid-treated samples, so that the surface areas and pore volumes of sulfuric acid-treated catalysts showed higher than citric acid-treated catalysts. Meanwhile, the acid treatments could release Al and Si species of catalyst which causing structural defect and widening the pore. This fact is supported by the increased in crystallinity and Si/Al ratio explaining the structural changing by the matrix material. Therefore, it can be concluded that the changed in matrix material with changes in the texture properties of the catalyst is preferable during the acid treatment [8,22]. As a result of releasing material from the pore channel during the acid treatment, the total pore volume increased due to the expense of the micropore and mesopore volumes. This pore size distribution detected using BJH method (Fig. 3) shows that the pore size distribution range of the acids-treated catalysts have similar to non-treated catalysts and centered at 3.0–4.5 nm at various acid concentrations. All catalysts have various pore volumes, according to Fig. 3. At some point, the acid-treated catalysts have lower pore volume than the non-treated catalyst. However, it is clear that the high acid concentration for catalyst treatment mainly shows higher pore volume. This data explains that the acids treatment of spent RFCC catalyst caused an increase of pore volume, both V micro and V meso, but the main contribution to the increase in V total came from the increase of V meso. 3.1.4 Acid sites properties of catalysts In order to analyze the changes of acid site concentration and type of each non- and acid-treated catalyst, the Py-FTIR analysis was used to determine the properties of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. A pyridine was used as a probe molecule to characterize solid acid sites, because pyridine forms complex bonds with acid sites that are easily detected in the spectrum [23]. Concerning the type of acid sites using FTIR, the pyridine adsorption to Brønsted acid sites detected in the band at approximately 1545 cm−1, while pyridine adsorption to Lewis acid sites is detected at approximately 1445 cm−1. Thus, the band at 1490 cm−1 is a shared contribution of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [24]. However, the band at 1490 cm−1 is rarely used to determine the number of Brønsted or Lewis acid sites because the number of these two acid sites cannot be distinguished. Prior to the measurement using FTIR, the physisorbed-pyridine molecules were desorbed at 150 °C; therefore, the measured adsorbed-pyridine molecules were chemically adsorbed on acid sites of catalysts. The concentrations of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were calculated, and the results are shown in Table 4 . The measurement of acid sites concentration on acid treated spent RFCC catalyst was revealed at different results of sulfuric acid treatment and citric acid treatment. The sulfuric acid treatment shows the total acid sites tended to decrease after being acid-treated. The total acid sites decreased as the concentration of sulfuric acid-treatment increased, except for the sample S(0.3)-RFCC. The amount of Brønsted acid site decreased after the sulfuric acid treatment, which is caused by the destruction of the Si−O−Al structure leading to decreasing Brønsted acid site in the framework. Besides, Lewis acid site decreased due to the removal of extra-framework Al (EFAl) [25]. For the S(0.3)-RFCC catalyst, the Lewis acid concentration increased from 70.22 to 128.91 mol/g, while the Brønsted acid concentration decreased. Fig. 4 (A) shows the band intensity at 1545 cm−1 (Brønsted acid site) decreased with concentration of sulfuric acid-treatment. Likewise, the band intensity at 1445 cm−1 (Lewis acid site) decreased with concentration of sulfuric acid treatment, except for the S(0.3)-RFCC. Since Lewis acid site degradation is more significant than Brønsted acid site during the sulfuric acid treatment, these catalysts have a larger Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) ratio. As mentioned, the sulfuric acid increases the B/L due to decreased Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, however, the decrease in the Lewis acid site is more significant. The decrease in the Lewis acid site is attributed by the removal of EFAl component. On the other hand, the decrease in the Brønsted acid site is attributed to the FAl. It is believed that the Brønsted acid site was generated by the presence of Si−(OH)−Al bridge in the zeolite structure. Since the FAl is removed from the framework, the Si−(OH)−Al bridge is collapsed. As a result, the Brønsted acid site decreases significantly. Furthermore, the FAl is released from the framework to the extra-framework as EFAl which can act as Lewis acid site. However, in a high sulfuric acid concentration, the EFAl can be removed from the catalyst by the excess acid solution. As reported, extra-framework cations could be completely removed by sulfuric acid with a high concentration [26]. Thereafter, the Lewis acid site decreases, resulting in the increase of B/L ratio. In contrast, the total acid sites concentration of the treated catalysts increased significantly (Table 4). The total acid sites increased as the citric acid concentration increased. This result is considered due to the increase of Lewis acid sites as the band intensity at 1445 cm−1 increased obviously with the citric acid-treatment concentrations. On the other hand, the Brønsted acid site decreased more than half after citric acid treatment, except for C(0.3)-RFCC and C(1.0)-RFCC. Fig. 4(B) shows that the band intensity at 1545 cm−1 decreased as citric acid-treatment concentrations increased. The increasing amount of Lewis acid site during the citric acid treatment is caused by dealumination of catalyst during the treatment. As reported by Zaiku et al. [27], citric acid treatment could dealuminate at a Si(2Al) site of zeolite beta. On the other hand, citric acid can rearrange the aluminosilicate framework of catalyst by the realumination at a Si(0Al) site [21,27]. In this case, the Al was removed from framework and partially converted into extra-framework. However, the removal of this EFAl is not significant since the citric acid is a weak organic acid. The positive charge of EFAl (cation) form supplied some Lewis acid site on the catalyst [28]. Narbeshuber et al. [29] and de Lucas et al. [30] also stated that the positive charge of EFAl could be partially neutralized by electron donation from the oxygen hydroxyl group, which acted as a Brønsted acid site on catalyst, which in turn decreasing amount of Brønsted acid sites during the citric acid treatment. However, the dealumination process during the citric acid treatment causes destruction of the Al framework and lost some parts of the Brønsted acid site. It is suggested that sulfuric acid and citric acid treatment have different mechanisms to influence the acidity of the spent RFCC catalyst. Lewis and Brønsted acid sites decreased during sulfuric acid treatment because of the removal of Al framework (FAl) and EFAl. On the other hand, citric acid treatment leads to converting some FAl to EFAl during dealumination and generates some Lewis acid site. However, Brønsted acid sites were lost through dealumination of FAl and cationic EFAl. In addition, the RFCC catalyst was designed to have some rare-earth metals (RE) (La, Ce, Y, Pr, Nd) (Table 2) to improve the effectiveness of the catalyst [2]. Besides, RE metals affect the acidity of the catalyst due to the coordination bond between RE cations and oxygen atoms in the framework. The Brønsted acid sites were generated through the polarization of RE cations, and the hydrolysis of RE cations [3]. XRF analysis of metals content shows that RE metal decreased after acid treatments of sulfuric acid and citric acid. Therefore, it could be another reason for the reduced amount of Brønsted acid site. 3.2 Catalytic performance testing on cracking palm oil to biofuels The performance of non- and acid- treated spent RFCC catalysts were evaluated in a continuous fixed-bed reactor for catalytic cracking palm oil as feedstock to produce biofuels (gasoline, kerosene, and/or diesel hydrocarbons ranges). The main products of this catalytic process were organic liquid products (OLP) of biofuels, byproducts, gas, and coke deposition. Fig. 5 shows that the non-treated (Spent RFCC) catalyst produces high OLP yield which still has potential to be reused for catalytic cracking palm oil, with the detailed information shown in Table 5 . However, the non-treated catalyst produces high coke yield, which can reduce catalyst lifetime due to the deactivation by pore coke blocking. Sulfuric acid and citric acid treatment on the spent RFCC catalyst can influence the catalytic activity by increasing the surface area, pore volume, crystallinity, and affect the concentration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the catalysts. From Fig. 5, it shows that both sulfuric acid and citric acid treatments gave almost similar reaction performance in term of cracking product distribution, where the OLP yield increased as increasing the acids treatment concentrations, while the coke yield decreased. The highest OLP yield was obtained when using sulfuric acid-treated catalysts, i.e. S(1.5)-RFCC catalyst of 93.52%. This yield was slightly higher than using the RFCC catalyst (non-treated) with OLP yield of 91.18% (Fig. 5(A)). The OLP yield of S(0.3)-RFCC, S(0.5)-RFCC, S(0.7)-RFCC, S(1.0)-RFCC catalysts have lower than when using the RFCC catalyst. On the other hand, the coke formation decreases as acid treating concentration increases when using sulfuric acid-treated catalysts, except for S(1.5)-RFCC catalyst. However, the amount of coke formation when using S(1.5)-RFCC catalyst was still lower than when using the non-treated RFCC catalyst. Furthermore, the highest OLP yield was obtained by using C(1.0)-RFCC catalyst of 94.74% when using the citric acid-treated catalysts. In this study, it was found that the yield of coke deposition decreased after acid treatment which was due to the reduction of metal contaminants, such as Ni, Fe, and V, which led to the increased coke formation. In addition, the opening of large pore after the acid treatment has shorter diffusion path length, which in turn the large molecules, as coke precursor formation, was easily diffused out from the catalyst pores, so that the coke formation was inhibited [31,32]. It is suggested that the modified spent RFCC catalysts are more suitable to produce kerosene-diesel range hydrocarbons which probably due to the large surface area and pore size. Luz et al. [33] explained that high average pore size, which is indirectly related to the presence of mesopores over the catalyst, could produce the high selectivity of heavy hydrocarbons, because of no diffusion barriers for heavy components. However, the acidic sites, such as Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, located in the pores encourage the cracking process and produce a variety of products. Fig. 5 illustrates the OLP distribution of gasoline and kerosene-diesel fraction selectivity. The gasoline and kerosene-diesel fractions contented on the OLP were determined according to the boiling point range of the gasoline and kerosene-diesel fractions using batch distillation at atmospheric pressure, where the temperature range of 39–204 °C (CAS 86290-81-5) was intended for gasoline fraction, while the kerosene-diesel was at a temperature range of 204–370 °C (3675 K/24/DJM/2006; 17.K/72/DJM/1999). It can be observed that the selectivity of gasoline and kerosene-diesel gradually increased over the acid-treated catalysts. However, the RFCC (non-treated) catalyst did not produce gasoline fraction during distillation process, while the selectivity of gasoline when using the C(X)-RFCC catalysts are higher than the S(X)-RFCC catalysts at the same acid treating concentration. This indicated that the citric acid-treated catalysts promote producing more gasoline range than the sulfuric acid-treated catalyst. The catalytic cracking activity was mainly influenced by the increase in catalyst properties, such as acidity and pore property (porosity) [34]. The presence of Brønsted acid site led to the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons and opposite to Lewis acid site [13]. The selectivity of gasoline increased with the acid concentration for catalyst treatment, except for S(1.0)-RFCC and C(1.0)-RFCC catalysts. The C(X)-RFCC catalysts produce higher gasoline range due to its lower Brønsted to Lewis (B/L) ratio than the S(X)-RFCC catalysts (Table 4). Fig. 5 shows that various concentrations of acid for treatment affect the fraction of gasoline and kerosene-diesel ranges products. Increasing the concentration of acid treatment, i.e. sulfuric acid and citric acid, affects on producing higher gasoline and kerosene-diesel ranges. It can be suggested that the acid-treated catalysts could improve the catalytic cracking performance of palm oil by influencing the physico- and chemico- properties of catalysts, like acidity, type of acid sites, and pore properties, which in turn enhanced the cracking process. 3.3 Effect of different acid-treated types on chemical composition of kerosene-diesel fraction Chemical components determination of the distilled kerosene-diesel product was performed using GC-MS (Table 6 ), which is grouped into hydrocarbons and oxygenated compounds. The oxygenated compounds are further divided into fatty acids, alcohols, and ketones according to their functional groups. However, the different acid treatment resulted the different amounts of chemical compositions of kerosene-diesel product, where the hydrocarbons remained dominant. The C(X)-RFCC catalysts produced more hydrocarbons ranges than the S(X)-RFCC catalysts. The different amounts of oxygenated compounds explained that deoxygenation reaction (decarbonylation and/or decarboxylation) occurs during the catalytic cracking palm oil using the modified spent RFCC catalysts. It is in accordance with the catalytic cracking mechanism suggested by Melero et al. [35]. They justified that after triglycerides are thermally decomposed to produce heavy oxygenated hydrocarbon compounds, such as fatty acids, the C–O and C–C bonds are broken at the β-scission through decarboxylation and decarbonylation reaction followed by a further cracking process over acid sites yielding hydrocarbons and oxygenated compounds [36]. The presence of oxygenated compounds after the cracking process justified the occurrence of incomplete deoxygenation reactions or the results of complex cracking reactions [12,37,38]. The oxygenated compounds of kerosene-diesel range product increased as the amount of acid sites on the catalyst decreased, where the S(X)-RFCC catalysts had lower Brønsted and Lewis acid sites than the C(X)-RFCC catalysts. It is revealed that the amount of acid sites on the catalyst can influence the deoxygenation reaction, so that the higher number of acid sites on catalyst produce more hydrocarbons. As reported by Ibarra et al. [39], the direct impact of a large amounts of active sites on the catalyst is the increase in deoxygenation reactions. Furthermore, the Lewis acid site promotes the decarboxylation reaction by producing higher hydrocarbon compounds [40,41]. Meanwhile, the Brønsted acid site leads to deoxygenation and aromatization reactions [42,43]. The GC-MS identification of kerosene-diesel fraction shows the presence of hydrocarbon chain range of C9-C25 (totally), leading to higher amount of C13–C19 (Fig. 6 ). The presence of hydrocarbons chain length of C9–C15 were produced by cracking and deoxygenation mechanisms, where the breaking CO and CC bonds through two different mechanisms depending on the initial compound. This behavior can be associated to palm oil compositions, which has a higher palmitic (C16:0) and olefin (C18:1) acids. From palmitic acid (saturated fatty acid), deoxygenation reaction occurs first due to the carbon bond of the carbonyl group was weaker [35,44]. From oleic acid (unsaturated fatty acid), the cleavage of the bond through the β-scission double bond (CC) occurs before the deoxygenation reaction, followed by a radical reaction producing hydrocarbons and oxygenated compounds with different carbon chain lengths and resulting the complexity of the cracking products [33,45]. In addition, the C(X)-RFCC sample favored to produce more cyclic hydrocarbons due to the cyclization reaction, which converting olefins into cyclic hydrocarbons. Besides, the C(X)-RFCC catalysts also produced ketone (2-heptadecanone) through ketonization of fatty acid. It is true since the C(X)-RFCC has higher amount of Lewis acid site, where cyclization of olefin and ketonization reactions were promoted by Lewis acid site [42]. 4 Conclusion Both sulfuric acid- and citric acid- treatments on the spent RFCC catalyst showed beneficial changes on the catalyst physicochemical properties. The acids treatment could remove the metals content on catalysts, so that the increased the specific surface area and pore volume of S(X)-RFCC and C(X)-RFCC catalysts. The sulfuric acid treatment increases the Brønsted to Lewis (B/L) ratio, while the citric acid-treatment decreases the B/L ratio. Higher yields of gasoline and kerosene-diesel and lower yield of coke were observed in the products of acid-treated catalyst cracking. The S(X)-RFCC catalyst results in higher amount of kerosene-diesel fraction than that of the C(X)-RFCC catalyst, where the C(X)-RFCC catalyst produces more gasoline fraction. It was due to the higher B/L ratio in the S(X)-RFCC catalyst, where Brønsted acid site led to the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons, while Lewis acid site led to the formation of short-chain hydrocarbons. Moreover, different acid types resulted in different main chemical composition of kerosene-diesel product, where the C(X)-RFCC catalyst produced more hydrocarbons than that of S(X)-RFCC catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the reactivation and modification of the spent Residue Fluid Catalytic Cracking (RFCC) catalyst using sulfuric acid and citric acid as acids treatment was evaluated by varying the acid solution concentrations. The effect of acid types and acid-solution concentrations on structural, textural, and acidic properties of spent RFCC catalyst was observed using X-ray diffraction, X-ray fluorescence, N2-sorption and pyridine-probed Fourier transform infrared measurements. Catalytic cracking of palm oil was used to evaluate the catalytic activity of the acid-treated catalysts. All the results showed the different beneficial effects of the sulfuric acid- and citric acid- treatments on the physicochemical properties of the modified catalyst with an improvement of surface area and pore volume of catalysts as well as the crystallinity due to the metal and matrix material removal. The sulfuric acid-treated catalysts have higher Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) ratio than the citric acid treatment, while the citric acid-treated catalysts have lower B/L ratio due to the enhancement of Lewis acid site. The acid-treated catalysts showed better performance than the non-treated catalyst. The selectivity of the kerosene-diesel range product fraction increased with the acid concentrations treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Acids treatment for improving catalytic properties and activity of the spent RFCC catalyst for cracking of palm oil to kerosene-diesel fraction fuels
